Design Option 4:
//IMG//

An architect is helping an organization with the Conceptual Design of an NSX-T Data Center solution.
The conceptual design includes these requirements, assumptions, constraints, and risks:
✑ Critical applications must run across sites without changing IP address.
✑ Business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) plans will leverage a second site running vSphere.
✑ RTO/RPO must be reduced for recovery of applications on secondary site.
✑ IT Teams require automation tools for configuration.
Which Conceptual Design would the architect recommend to the customer? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer: B Design option 2

choices.B: NSX Manager OAuth 2.0 registered to a 2-node VMware Identity Manager cluster.
choices.A: NSX Manager OAuth 2.0 registered to a 3-node Active Directory Federation Services cluster.
choices.C: NSX Manager OAuth 2.0 registered to a 2-node Active Directory Federation Services cluster
choices.D: NSX Manager OAuth 2.0 registered to a 3-node VMware Identity Manager cluster.

discussion.content: Setting up a VMware Identity Manager cluster with three nodes is recommended. This is based on this link: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Workspace-ONE-Access/19.03/vidm-install/GUID-3BFB1D4D-D5C2-480D-94E0-31ED6B0CAA63.html

comments.content: D, a 3 node cluster is recommended.

questions.question_text:
A customer deploying NSX-T Data Center requires role based access controls be enforced in NSX Manager with these requirements:
✑ identity platform must be highly available
✑ authentication must be performed by customer's existing SAML identity provider
✑ MFA must be performed by administrator to gain access to NSX Manager
Which identity deployments would meet the customer's requirements? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content:
D is the correct answer.

1 – Datacenter level
2 - Environment (Prod, Dev, Test) level
3 - Security Group (High Risk, Medium Risk, Low Risk) level
4 – Tier (DB, WEB, APP) level

Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer: D

Correct answer is D for the following reasons:
Each circle in this design is a "level" starting at the most granular level which is the sub-component of the app (web, db., or app), then risk level (high, med, low) then deployment zone (prod, dev, test), and then finally infrastructure services level.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

A financial company is adopting micro-services with the intent of simplifying network security. An NSX-T architect is proposing a NSX-T Data Center micro- segmentation logical design. The architect has created a diagram to share with the customer.
How many security levels will be implemented according to this Logical Design? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content:
For me C is the correct.

You can attach an N-VDS to both an Overlay and a VLAN transport zone, and you can do it also as with N-VDS having a different name or the same name.

Single N-VDS can carry the traffic of both the Overlay transport zone and the VLAN transport zone.
http://www.vmwarearena.com/how-to-create-nsx-t-transport-zone-vmware-nsx-t-part-7/#:~:text=So%20the%20transport%20zone%20is,and%20the%20VLAN%20transport%20zone.
clearly it's A. C is a sentence that makes no sense.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Based on the ICM textbook:
Each N-VDS or VDS switch can be associated with one or more transport zones

Please read the question carefully, its mentioned as "can", so A,B,C all the are correct.
Its just knowledge check for the exam.

C is correct if is free of errors: C. 
An N-VDS can attach to both an Overlay and a VLAN transport zone.

Otherwise the only one making sense is A as 2nd option.
Single N-VDS can carry the traffic of both the Overlay transport zone and the VLAN transport zone.

comments.content: Reading again the question, the answer is C

discussion.content:
https://images.nsx.techzone.vmware.com/sites/default/files/NSX-T%20Reference%20Design%20Guide%203-0.pdf

An NSX virtual switch (N-VDS or VDS with NSX) can attach to a single overlay
transport zone and multiple VLAN transport zones at the same time-->Page 25.
Clearly A

Correct answer is "C". Single N-VDS can carry the traffic of both the Overlay transport zone and the VLAN transport zone.
http://www.vmwarearena.com/how-to-create-nsx-t-transport-zone-vmware-nsx-t-part-7/

choices.C: An N-VDS can attach to both an Overlay and a VLAN transport zone to a N-VDS having different name/s.
choices.D: An N-VDS must be disabled before attaching both Overlay and VLAN transport zones.
choices.A: An N-VDS can only attach to a single Overlay transport zone.
choices.B: An N-VDS can only attach to a single VLAN transport zone.
